(3, 1, 1): Reading comprehension, analytical reasoning, logical reasoning, and (unscored) writing.
(4, 1, 1): Admissions to Juris Doctor (JD) programs of law schools in the United States, Canada, and some other countries.
(6, 1, 1): 35 minutes for each of the 5 sections, for a total of 2 hours and 55 minutes (excluding breaks).
(8, 1, 1): Scores of up to 12 tests taken since June  1, 2008 are valid.
(9, 1, 1): In 2018, 5 times: February, June, July, September, and November.
(10, 1, 1): Starting September 2019, no more than 3 attempts in one LSAC year (June-May), no more than 5 attempts in 5 years, no more than 7 attempts in a lifetime. Exceptions may be granted for special circumstances.
(13, 1, 1): No official prerequisite. Intended for bachelor's degree graduates and undergraduate students about to graduate, who want to apply to law schools. Fluency in English assumed.
(14, 1, 1): US$190. ,  (US, Canadian and Australian citizens with extreme financial need may be granted fee waivers valid for two tests in a two-year period.)
(15, 1, 1): Law schools in United States, Canada, Australia and some other countries.
